title: 106_s1259
content:
The "Trademark Amendments Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. Dilution can be used as grounds for opposition and cancellation. (a) Registrable Marks.--The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include provisions for refusing registration and canceling registration of marks that would cause dilution under section 43(c).
(b) Opposition.--Section 13(a) of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include dilution as a ground for opposition and cancellation. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include provisions for refusing registration and canceling registration of marks that would cause dilution under section 43(c). Amendments also apply to petitions to cancel registrations and effective dates for applications filed after January 16, 1996. SEC. 3. REMEDIES IN CASES OF DILUTION OF FAMOUS MARKS. Injunctions and damages under the Trademark Act of 1946 are amended to include provisions for violations under section 43(a) or (c). Destruction of articles is also addressed for violations under section 43(a) or willful violations under section 43(c). SEC. 4. Liability of governments for trademark infringement and dilution is amended under section 32 of the Trademark Act of 1946 to include the United States, its agencies, instrumentalities, and individuals acting on behalf of the United States in cases of violations under section 43(a) or willful violations under section 43(c). The United States, its agencies, instrumentalities, and individuals acting on behalf of the United States shall not be immune from suit in Federal or State court for any violation under the Trademark Act of 1946. Under this Act, any State waives sovereign immunity. The definition of "person" in the Trademark Act of 1946 now includes the United States, its agencies, instrumentalities, and individuals acting on behalf of the United States. The United States, its agencies, and individuals acting on its behalf are subject to the provisions of this Act in the same way as any non-governmental entity. SEC. 5 amends Section 43(a) of the Trademark Act of 1946 regarding civil actions for trade dress infringement. It places the burden of proof on the person asserting trade dress protection for unregistered trade dress to show it is not functional. SEC. 6 includes technical amendments. SEC. 6 of the Trademark Act of 1946 makes technical amendments related to the assignment of marks and clerical changes to the text and title of the Act.
